data: {"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3156657,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-03T18:53:11.072Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eHi everybody,\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne of our students has been working for several days to tune out the coupling between rotational and translation motion that we’re seeing: the robot tends to “veer” slightly in the direction of the spin, and we’d like to eliminate that.  It’s mainly a problem when going fast (\u0026gt;3 m/s, \u0026gt;2rad/s) and autonomously.  Driving manually, the driver seems to unconsciously correct for this effect, but in fast autonomous spinning movement there’s no good cartesian reference, so no way to correct it until the vision system reacquires everything.  We’ve investigated various causes, such as lag in the drive controllers, but we haven’t found anything really clear.  I’m curious if any experienced swerve control optimization folks have encountered this coupling, and what you did about it.  thanks!\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2023-03-03T18:53:11.072Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":30,"reads":108,"readers_count":107,"score":171.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":428795,"topic_slug":"swerve-controls-rotation-translation-coupling","display_username":"joel
